author: @mikaelnissen4789
text: I had a lot of trouble installing all lib etc and find it much easier building package with docker:  get docker container from: https://hub.docker.com/r/kivy/buildozer with: docker pull kivy/buildozer init file: docker run --rm --volume "$HOME/.buildozer":/home/user/.buildozer --volume "$PWD":/home/user/hostcwd kivy/buildozer init build code: docker run --rm --volume "$HOME/.buildozer":/home/user/.buildozer --volume "$PWD":/home/user/hostcwd kivy/buildozer -v android debug deploy run

text: It's probably taking long the first time to download the specific API first to use to build against, and you can use ADB to debug android apps

author: @12345charliebrown
text: the one thing holding me back from migrating over from python2 to python3 was Buildozer because I remember what a pain in the ass it was before I just didn't want to mess things up on my development OS so I stuck with it now trying Buildozer with Python3 code...wish me luck....   Edit: It worked. Just had to install the correct version of Cython for Python3. Don't update Cython as instructed in the installation page, I had issues with it. Instead, read this link https://kivy.org/doc/stable/installation/deps-cython.html . Also, as I recall I had issues with the latest versions of Java I installed Java8 instead and set it as default. Just my 2 cents.

author: @JohnDupuyCOMO
text: You can also test against Android Studio on Ubuntu. Essentially, a "virtual" software phone pops up. You can setup many profiles to run against so that you try out virtual tablets and different resolutions and capabilities. Don't know if it has changed recently, but buildozer will include some required permissions by default. You can remove them by hacking the generated XML files. I've got a game on Google Play (called Kalah Mancala) that requests zero permissions.  ... That reminds me, I need to do an update on that app.
